blog.description:
FAQ

unforgivably cursing you with our existence since 1965

as seen in Bo Burnham's Eighth Grade, apparently

we have a Discord server! join here! (15+ only please)

we track the tag 'accioshitpost' (without a dash) so if you have art or a fic based on of one of our posts, pop it in there and we'll reblog it for you! we always appreciate your creativity!

you can find our amazon wishlists here and here - if you get us anything, we'll post a picture and a thank you note!!

if you want to follow our personal blogs, here's Roxie's, here's Persephone's, and here's Jamie's

nazis, terfs, pedos, and anybody happy to defend or stand by them can leave. we don't want you. avada kedavra, shithead.

now in blue raspberry flavours, hitting stores soon!

body:
the girl who had nerve

Harry Potter lived knowing that his greatest weapon - the power the Dark Lord knew not - was Love. He was pure and good and moral, despite of everything trying to darken him. He was never capable of throwing a killing curse, and he never did.

Ginny Weasley, however, who had blood on her hands and bile in her mouth before she even had a bra- she knew beyond a shadow of a doubt that the Killing Curse would not hesitate on her lips. When Harry Potter was announced dead from the cruel, razor sharp voice that she still shook her head free from now and again- Ginny didn’t scream. She didn’t cry. She didn’t mourn. She didn’t hesitate.

summary: 7 Reasons Rowling Deserves Nobel Prize An Introduction to a Formalist Reading
title: 7 Reasons Rowling Deserves Nobel Prize An Introduction to a Formalist Reading
excerpt: The Nobel Prize for Literature has a storied history as the most important recognition an author can receive but it has taken quite a few hits of late with respect to its respectability.
description: The simple fact is, though no living author’s work has ever been the subject of as much critical attention as has Rowling’s Harry Potter novels, this tsunami of academic literature has done very little to raise her reputation as a writer. Besides the rush of new work in the field — I think of Shira Wolosky’s Riddles of Harry Potter, Beatrice Groves’ Literary Allusion in Harry Potter, and Patrick McCauley’s Into the Pensieve — little of the quality anthologized essays or book length treatments that take Harry and his creator seriously as literature has penetrated the public or media mind.

reblog.comment: The simple fact is, though no living author’s work has ever been the subject of as much critical attention as has Rowling’s Harry Potter novels, this tsunami of academic literature has done very little to raise her reputation as a writer. Besides the rush of new work in the field — I think of Shira Wolosky’s Riddles of Harry Potter, Beatrice Groves’ Literary Allusion in Harry Potter, and Patrick McCauley’s Into the Pensieve — little of the quality anthologized essays or book length treatments that take Harry and his creator seriously as literature has penetrated the public or media mind.

trail.content_raw: The simple fact is, though no living author’s work has ever been the subject of as much critical attention as has Rowling’s Harry Potter novels, this tsunami of academic literature has done very little to raise her reputation as a writer. Besides the rush of new work in the field — I think of Shira Wolosky’s Riddles of Harry Potter, Beatrice Groves’ Literary Allusion in Harry Potter, and Patrick McCauley’s Into the Pensieve — little of the quality anthologized essays or book length treatments that take Harry and his creator seriously as literature has penetrated the public or media mind.
trail.content: The simple fact is, though no living author’s work has ever been the subject of as much critical attention as has Rowling’s Harry Potter novels, this tsunami of academic literature has done very little to raise her reputation as a writer. Besides the rush of new work in the field — I think of Shira Wolosky’s Riddles of Harry Potter, Beatrice Groves’ Literary Allusion in Harry Potter, and Patrick McCauley’s Into the Pensieve — little of the quality anthologized essays or book length treatments that take Harry and his creator seriously as literature has penetrated the public or media mind.

tags: The Lion the witch and the wardrobe
summary: Do you ever look back at the movies of your childhood and realise that it was pretty awesome? We had The Lion, The Witch and The...
body:
Do you ever look back at the movies of your childhood and realise that it was pretty awesome? We had The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe, along with Peter Pan. Disney movies were in thier prime, with Beauty and the Beast, The Little Mermaid, Tarzan and Mulan. Disney Channel was even doing fairly well during most of the time… Of course, I’m not even counting Harry Potter..

Don’t you just want to do it all again? Rewind the clock and learn to dream again?

summary: Harry Potter characters as things I’ve said
body:
Harry Potter characters as things I’ve said

Harry: *passes a class by 0.4%* “God is real”

Ron: “I love your jumper!” *is a jacket*

Hermione: “You are so smart I wish I was just like you”

Neville: *trips on a sidewalk and doesn’t fall* “Yes bitch I am alive and thriving”

Luna: “Bless you!” … “oh wait did you sneeze?”

Draco: “My ancestors are shaking at how stupid you are”

Ginny: “I’m gonna deck you so hard you’ll be shitting out your insides”

Ron: “Life would be better if you just got laid”

Neville: “When I can walk in a straight line it is over for you bitches”

Draco: I’m so basic bitch material even my blood type is A positive

Ginny: “I will murder you and I will sleep peacefully at night”

Hermione: “You’re so… interesting”

Harry: “I hope you step on a lego and I hope it hurts

Luna: “If I sleep when we hang out it’s because I love you and it’s not because I only slept for 45 minutes”
